topics.body:
To get the area of  a triangle given three points(A,B, and C) on a coordinate plan, you must first find the distance between each point. To do this you must use the distance formula. The distance between two pints is equal to the square root of (x ~2~-x ~1~) ^2^ + (y ~2~-y ~1~) ^2^
After that you will need to find the semiperimeter. The semiperimeter is half the perimeter. Hence the semi part.

Then, use all of your training to find the area using Heron's formula. The area is equal to the square root of S(S-a)(S-b)(S-c). Where:
S=semiperimeter
a=distance between points B and C
b=distance between points A and C
c=distance between points A and B
topics.author: 52f0834d63687261cba90300

"@Albus Fahrenheits":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/54ac95516368727594e20600#post_54ac95516368727594e20600
[bq="Albus Fahrenheits"]To get the area of  a triangle given three points(A,B, and C) on a coordinate plan, you must first find the distance between each point. To do this you must use the distance formula. The distance between two pints is equal to the square root of (x ~2~-x ~1~) ^2^ + (y ~2~-y ~1~) ^2^
After that you will need to find the semiperimeter. The semiperimeter is half the perimeter. Hence the semi part.

Then, use all of your training to find the area using Heron's formula. The area is equal to the square root of S(S-a)(S-b)(S-c). Where:
S=semiperimeter
a=distance between points B and C
b=distance between points A and C
c=distance between points A and B[/bq]


*rips up test*
